tossups.question: A di-halogenated version of this compound is converted to an allene using an organolithium base in the Skattebøl rearrangement. This compound is added to an aromatic ring after the 1st step of the Buchner ring expansion. This compound was first synthesized via a sodium-mediated Wurtz coupling by August Freund. This compound was hypothesized to have sp2 hybridized orbitals in the Walsh model. Diethyl (*) zinc is added to one reaction that produces this compound to improve reactivity. In that reaction, an alkene and a carbenoid intermediate react in the presence of di-iodo-methane and a zinc-copper couple to produce this planar molecule. For 10 points, name this smallest cyclic alkane, which is produced in the Simmons-Smith reaction.
tossups.answer: cyclopropane [accept C3H6; do not accept or prompt on propane]

tossups.question: A David Haig play about the relationship between this author and his son is titled after his poem “My Boy Jack.” This author addressed to the “Lord of our far-flung battle line” a poem that repeats the refrain “Lest we forget.” Another poem by this author advises not to “make dreams your master” before calling (*) Triumph and Disaster “two impostors.” This poet of “Recessional” penned the line “East is East and West is West, and never the twain shall meet.” A poem by this author ends by exclaiming “You’ll be a man, my son!” and begins many of its lines with the title conjunction. This author advocated for American occupation of the Philippines in “The White Man’s Burden.” For 10 points, name this author of the poem“If--” who wrote about Mowgli in The Jungle Book.
tossups.answer: Rudyard Kipling

tossups.question: In one work by this artist, two elongated “personages” overlook a flame symbolizing sexual embrace. Three bronze moon-shaped objects are stacked on each other in a sculpture by this artist in the Hirschhorn. He’s not Brancusi, but this artist sought to display movement and infinity with his monochrome “Bird in Space” Triptychs. Altamira cave paintings inspired this artist’s depiction of a (*) plowman in a work that also includes a newspaper titled “Jour.” A stylized bird “reveals the unknown to a pair of lovers” in one of this artist’s 24 Constellation paintings. Multicolored animals are scattered across the sky, sea, and earth sections of another work by this artist that depicts his family’s farm. For 10 points, name this Catalonian surrealist of The Tilled Field.
tossups.answer: Joan Miro (The 1st clue refers to Miro’s Peinture at the Guggenheim; the 2nd clue refers to Miro’s Lunar Bird sculpture)

tossups.question: A member of this family prevented Ogilvy Berlouis from overthrowing France-Albert René in Operation Flowers are Blooming. Another member of this family was accused of illegal dealings with Ottavio Quattrocchi due to his Italian-born wife. That member of this family faced protests after advocating for alimony to be paid to (*) Shah Bano. Another member of this family enforced compulsory sterilization during a period known as the “Emergency”. That man’s brother was assassinated by the Tamil Tigers. This family has held control over the INC for most of its history. For 10 points, name this family, whose members include Indian prime ministers Indira and Rajiv.
tossups.answer: Gandhi [accept Nehru-Gandhi; accept Sanjay Gandhi; accept Rajiv Gandhi; accept Indira Gandhi]

tossups.question: After a recently fired executive in this novel douses himself in gasoline, he observes a tryst between his wife and his former boss. A character in this novel tries to determine if she is a “sensitive” by staring at a picture of John Clerk Maxwell. Two characters in this novel watch a movie starring Baby Igor at a hotel where the band the Paranoids are staying. The radio DJ (*) Mucho is the husband of a character in this novel who has a brief affair with the lawyer Metzger. The protagonist of this novel sees the recurring symbol of a muted post horn and the mysterious acronym W.A.S.T.E. In this novel, the underground mail system Trystero is investigated by Oedipa Maas. For 10 points, name this short novel by Thomas Pynchon which ends at an auction.
tossups.answer: The Crying of Lot 49

tossups.question: Note to moderator: read the notes slowly, pausing between dashes. The slow movement of a symphony by this composer opens with a long E flat in strings, followed by these notes in a dotted rhythm: “F - G - A flat - F - E flat.” Another symphony by this composer opens with violins playing the notes “E-flat - D - D” three times, after which they rise to a high B-flat. Nikolaus Harnoncourt has argued that this composer’s final three symphonies should be viewed as a unified work. The finale of one of his symphonies begins with an arpeggiated G minor (*) Mannheim rocket and is one of the two symphonies this composer wrote in a minor key. This composer’s “great” G minor symphony was followed by one that ends with a five-voice fugato and is nicknamed for a Roman god. For 10 points, name this composer whose 41st and final symphony is nicknamed Jupiter.
tossups.answer: Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart

tossups.question: Smedley Butler was court-martialed for accusing a leader of this country of running over a child with his car. Violet Gibson shot a leader of this country in the nose after throwing a rock at his car’s windshield. A soldier from this country gained fame after dropping propaganda leaflets over Vienna during World War I. Forced ingestion of castor oil was used as a torture method in this country, which was led from the (*) Salo Republic. The Free State of Fiume was established by a leader of this country who promulgated the corporatist state. A 1922 march on this country’s capital was led by the Blackshirts. For 10 points, name this country whose nationalist movements were led by Gabriele d’Annunzio and Benito Mussolini.
tossups.answer: Kingdom of Italy [or fascist Italy]

tossups.question: An adiabatically tapered version of these devices serves as the cavity in a two-color dipole trapping scheme for observing quantum state-transfer. PLC and FBT are two types of passive, quartz-based splitters used in tandem with these devices. When these devices possess a parabolic spatial profile, they are classified as graded-index. That type of these devices is contrasted with their (*) step-index type, which possess a discontinuous index of refraction between their core and cladding. As the acceptance angle for these devices increases, so does their numerical aperture. These devices make use of total internal reflection to confine light along their length. For 10 points, name these optical waveguides that Google is using in their high-speed internet service.
tossups.answer: optical fibers [accept optical nanofibers, or fiber optic(s); prompt on fibers, (optical) waveguides, or Google Fiber]

tossups.question: A leader of this city reportedly wounded himself and claimed that there had been an assassination attempt on him; he was then granted a bodyguard that carried wooden clubs. That leader of this city gained favor by having a tall woman named Phya dress as a goddess and order the people to follow him. Another leader of this city enforced economic restrictions against Megara after they supposedly trespassed on the Hiera Orgas. A woman from (*) Miletus was vilified for having excessive control over a ruler of this city. This city was the site of a plague that killed Paralus, Xanthippus, and their father, who delivered a famous funeral oration. For 10 points, name this city, ruled by both Peisistratos and Pericles.
tossups.answer: Athens

tossups.question: Martin Lindstrom built on the idea of "glasses" for this concept as a method for understanding. C.P. Snow labeled varieties of this concept as "science" and "humanities" in a lecture that argued that Western society was splitting this concept. Radcliffe-Brown outlined a functionalist theory of this concept that claims that this concept adapts to (*) environments. Margaret Mead divided this concept into apollonian and dionysian forms and defined this concept as "personality writ large." In The Chrysanthemum and the Sword, Ruth Benedict outlined differences between the American and Japanese types of this concept, labeled as shame and guilt. For 10 points, name this concept which refers to the collective beliefs and customs of a group of people.
tossups.answer: culture

tossups.question: An inactive version of this disease’s causative organism is dissolved in mineral oil in the complete Freund’s adjuvant used in mouse research. That organism associated with this disease is the most prominent member of a genus that stains bright red in the presence of carbol fuchsin and methylene blue in the Ziehl-Neelson acid fast stain. The prefix “extensively” is added to a classification of this disease if that organism (*) resists fluoroquinolone antibiotics. Rifampin and isoniazid are two parts of the RIPE regimen for treating this disease. This disease is commonly diagnosed using either the Mendel-Mantoux skin test or with a lung x-ray. For 10 points, name this disease caused by a mycobacterium and historically known as consumption.
tossups.answer: tuberculosis [accept TB; accept mycobacterium tuberculosis; prompt on consumption until mention]

tossups.question: “Questions of truth” and “questions of virtue” arise in Michael McKeon’s Marxist study of the origins of this thing. Steven Moore has released two volumes of an “alternative history” about this thing. Social conditions in the 18th century influenced the “rise” of this thing, according to a book by Ian Watt. The terms “flat” and “round” are used to describe people in this type of work in an (*) E.M. Forster book about its “aspects.” The “sensation” type of this work, popular in the Victorian era, includes The Woman in White. Lady Murasaki Shikibu wrote what may be the first of this type of work, The Tale of Genji. For 10 points, name this form of literature whose “Great American” type could be The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn.
tossups.answer: the novel [prompt on books, fiction, prose, or literature]

tossups.question: The Herem de-Rabbenu Gershom forbids a coerced form of this practice. Failure to undergo this practice can result in certain people becoming "agunah." In Judaism, this practice is accomplished with the receipt of a get. This practice is analogous to a result of the Pauline Privilege, which is performed if the participants were unbaptized at the time of a (*) previous ceremony. Khul is a form of this practice where the authority is given to women, while in Sunni Islam, this practice may occur when a man says "talaq" three times. The Catholic Church generally forbids this practice, instead allowing for annulments to take place. For 10 points, name this practice of ending a marriage.
tossups.answer: divorce [accept annulment before read; accept answers such as dissolution of marriage or ending a marriage before the last line]

tossups.question: This scientist is the alphabetically prior namesake of a function equal to the axisymmetric eigenfunctions of the curl operator for a force-free magnetic field. For homogenous, plane-parallel atmospheres with finite thicknesses, this scientist names two X and Y functions that approximate radiative transfer. With Mario Schonberg, this scientist names a limit below which main-sequence (*) stars with non-fusing, isothermal cores can support an enclosing envelope. A telescope named for this scientist was launched in 1999 to be NASA’s premier X-ray observatory. Electron degeneracy pressure gives rise to an upper bound of 1.4 solar masses for white dwarves in this scientist’s namesake “limit”. For 10 points, name this Indian-American astrophysicist.
tossups.answer: Subrahmanyan Chandrasekhar [accept Chandra Observatory; accept Chandrasekhar-Kendall equation/function, Chandrasekhar X-and-Y function, Schonberg-Chandrasekhar limit, or Chandrasekhar limit]

tossups.question: This body of water is home to St. Anastasia Island and the disputed Zmiinyi Island, known in English as Snake Island. A disputed region along this body of water has a green and white striped flag with a hand and seven stars in the upper left corner. One city on this body of water is Sukhumi, the capital of the separatist region (*) Abkhazia. This body of water lies south of the disputed Tuzla Island, which lies in the Kerch Strait. The cities of Stary Krym and Sevastopol are found in a disputed territory along the northern coast of this body of water. Crimea lies along the shore of, for 10 points, what sea south of Ukraine, which is separated from the Mediteranian by the Bosporus?
tossups.answer: Black Sea [accept Euxine Sea]

tossups.question: In an article titled "What Is" this field, Kit Fine claimed that this field had five features that separate it from other forms of enquiry. In "Pseudoproblems in Philosophy," Rudolf Carnap claimed that this field "seeks to find and express the knowledge that is inaccessible to empirical science." A.J. Ayer referred to this field as "unverifiable" and titled a chapter of Language, Truth, and Logic for the (*) "Elimination" of this field. A book titled for this field describes a combination of matter and form called hylomorphism. That book titled for this field opens with the phrase "All men by nature desire to know.”. For 10 points, name this field titled for a book by Aristotle which studies the fundamental nature of the world.
tossups.answer: metaphysics [accept metaphysica]

tossups.question: The hajichi type of this art form was practiced by Okinawan natives and commonly depicted spears and arrowheads. A form of this art form practiced by the Atayal forms a "V" pattern, and one form practiced by the Ainu often depicted smiling mouths and moustaches. Another form of this art form utilized a tool called an au (“ow”) and a pigment made from (*) soot. A Maori type of this art form depicts three-lined designs and is called ta moko. In modern Japan, this form of art is discouraged due to its association with Yakuza membership, and Orthodox Jews forbid this art form due to a passage in Leviticus banning body markings. For 10 points, name this form of body art, which is usually made by injecting ink into the skin.
tossups.answer: tattoos [prompt on body modification; prompt on body art; do NOT accept or prompt on "scarification"]

tossups.question: After leaving the band Ash Ra Tempel, an artist from this country recorded the hour-long, chess-inspired track E2-E4. The score to the film Sorcerer and the album Phaedra were released by a band from this country named Tangerine Dream. Damo Suzuki shouts “you’re losing” the title substance in a song from this country on the album Ege Bamyasi titled (*) “Vitamin C.” Can was a band from this country, where another group pioneered electronic music with the albums The Man-Machine and Trans-Europe Express. David Bowie recorded a trilogy of albums, including Heroes, in this country’s capital. A band from here, Nena, gained fame for a protest song whose English-language version is “99 Red Balloons.” For 10 points, name this country, the home of Kraftwerk and the genre of krautrock.
tossups.answer: Germany [or West Germany; or Federal Republic of Germany; or Deutschland]

tossups.question: In the preface to a novel, the author sees the Greek word Ananke etched into a wall in this place. Bragmardo makes a plea for one character to return objects he stole from this place to tie around his horse’s neck. A character who works here looks from a book to this place and says “This will kill that.” After climbing to the top of this structure, a giant (*) urinates on the crowd below in the novel Gargantua and Pantagruel. In a novel titled for this place, the protagonist saves a woman who is falsely accused of murdering Phoebus. That character, who is crowned the “Pope of Fools” at a festival, pushes Frollo off of the top of this building after he betrayed Esmeralda. For 10 points, name this building where, in a Victor Hugo novel, the hunchback Quasimoto works.
tossups.answer: Notre Dame Cathedral [accept The Hunchback of Notre Dame]

tossups.question: During a battle in this state, Louis Wigfall presented surrender terms to Union soldiers by himself in a rowboat without authorization from his commander. Former slaves were recruited for agricultural labor in this state in the Port Royal Experiment. In this state, William Carney earned a Medal of Honor for saving the flag while under the command of Robert Gould Shaw at (*) Fort Wagner. Abner Doubleday claimed to have fired the first return shot during a battle in this state. The Star of the West failed to reach Robert Anderson during a siege in this state. Fort Moultrie was bombarded by P.G.T. Beauregard in this state. For 10 points, name this state, which saw the first action of the Civil War at Fort Sumter.
tossups.answer: State of South Carolina

bonuses.leadin: In a novel by this author, a group of secret policemen hallucinate and take the form of a dragon after ingesting golden fish. For 10 points each:
answers: Russia [accept Soviet Union or Union of Soviet Socialist Republics]
parts: Name this author of Day of the Oprichnik. He also wrote about a race of blond-haired, blue-eyed people who congregate after the impact of the Tunguska meteorite in the Ice trilogy.
Sorokin is from this country. Yevgeny Zamyatin fictionalized this country’s totalitarian control in his novel We.
This author’s science fiction novels include one where Sharik is turned into the foul-mouthed dogcatcher Poligraf Poligrafovich titled Heart of a Dog.

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about artists serving as subjects for photographers. For 10 points each:
parts: Splashing water in the shape of a waterfall obscures the title artist who can be seen floating next to three black cats and one of his own paintings in “Dali Atomicus”, a work by this Lithuanian-American photographer.

This American photographer used a sculpture by his friend Auguste Rodin designed as a monument to Balzac for his photograph Towards the Light, Midnight. This artist co-founded the Photo-Secessionist movement with Alfred Stieglitz and organized the influential Family of Man exhibit in 1955.
While visiting his villa at La Rêve, Henri Cartier-Bresson photographed this other artist of Harmony in Red and The Dance as he sat amongst his pet birds in his studio.

bonuses.leadin: A revolt in this country led by a Jesus-like figure known as “the Counsellor” resulted in thousands of deaths in the Canudos. For 10 points each:
answers: Federative Republic of Brazil [or República Federativa do Brasil]
Lampião [or Virgulino Ferreira da Silva; prompt on partial]
Pedro [accept Pedro I or Pedro II]
parts: Name this country where cafe com leite politics dominated during the late 19th and early 20th centuries.

This famous Brazilian bandit or cangaceiro led a group of followers who killed their victims with knives called peixeiras, or “fish-filleters”. He was profiled in Eric Hobsbawm’s study of social banditry.
Brazil’s republic came to be after the overthrow of an emperor with this name. The only two emperors of Brazil both had this regnal name.

bonuses.leadin: Thin films of this compound can be doped with lanthanum to alter the properties of its standard “52/48” or “30/70” forms. For 10 points each:
answers: PZT [or lead zirconate titanate or PLZT or lead lanthanum zirconate titanate]
ferroelectric random access memory [or FRAM or static/dynamic/non-volatile RAM]
parts: Name this ceramic perovskite material that is ferroelectric at room temperature, in addition to being strongly piezoelectric. Devices made from this material are generally more effective than those made from barium titanate.

The usefulness of PZT also comes from its ability to exhibit this phenomenon at room temperatures. Generally, systems with this property show lag between inputs and outputs due to the system’s physical memory.

One of the most common uses of PZT is within the ferroelectric layer of chips for this most common type of computer memory. This type of memory comes in DIMM and SODIMM sizes and holds data currently in use.

bonuses.leadin: These two characters both fall in love with a woman they see picking flowers while they are in a nearby prison. For 10 points each:
answers: falling off a horse [accept descriptions; accept being crushed by a horse; the word “horse” is required]
parts: Name either of the cousins who fight for the love of Emily in “The Knight’s Tale.”
“The Knight’s Tale” is one of the many stories told by Pilgrims in this collection by Geoffrey Chaucer.
Although he wins Emily’s hand, divine intervention causes Arcite to die in this manner. Elsewhere in the Tales, the Manciple insults the Cook after the very drunk Cook does this action.

bonuses.leadin: White smoke can be seen emerging from a train passing across this structure in a work in which it is depicted with a dark blue and red color palette. For 10 points each:
answers: Charing Cross Bridge, London [prompt on partial answers]
parts: Name this bridge on the south shores of the Thames next to the Lion’s Brewery, which was painted while one artist was staying in London in the winter of 1906.

Andre Derain’s depiction of Charing Cross Bridge is regarded as one of the premier works of this art movement. This movement’s name was inspired by the critical reception of an Albert Marque sculpture as “Donatello among the wild beasts!”.

The name of Fauvism was coined at the 1905 version of this Salon, which heavily featured works by Derain and Matisse. This salon was created as a middle-ground between the official Salon and the Salon des Independents.

bonuses.leadin: One of these constructs named for Wald describes geometric Brownian motion for any real value of a constant lambda, and their decomposition is described by the Doob-Meyer theorem. For 10 points each:
answers: Norbert Weiner [or Wiener process; do not accept Levy process or Poisson process]
parts: Name these sequences of random variables, which at a particular time see the expectation value of the next value in the sequence equal the present value. They were named in reference to an 18th century betting strategy.

Martingales are useful for describing stochastic processes with countable numbers of elements, which are called this type of process in time. Processes described by this adjective are contrasted with continuous-time processes.

Wald’s martingale specifically applies to the continuous-time processes named for this American scientist. This namesake of a measure equivalent to the probability law for continuous functions is also the founder of cybernetics.

bonuses.leadin: King Zhou was so enraptured by this goddess’s beauty that he composed a lewd poem in her honor while making offerings. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this goddess who, in Chinese mythology, created humans by flicking a mud-covered rope. She is the consort of Fuxi.

King Zhou’s blasphemy leads to the downfall of the Shang dynasty as Nüwa sends this figure to him as a concubine. This figure sadistically tortured people by making them stand atop a heated bronze cylinder and once ordered a farmer's feet cut off so she could study them.
Daji was one of these animals, which often disguise themselves as beautiful women in East Asian folklore. Meeting one of these animals with nine tails is a sign of good fortune.

bonuses.leadin: During this battle, a baker-woman with six fingers on each hand apparently killed eight Castilian soldiers when they tried to hide from enemy forces. For 10 points each:
answers: John I [accept John I of Castile, John I of Portugal, John I of England]
parts: Name this 1385 battle which resulted in the rise of the Aviz Dynasty.
The Aviz Dynasty was a royal house in this Iberian country.

Both of the kings that fought at Aljubarrota had this regnal name and number. Another king with this name and number lost a battle where he allied with Holy Roman Emperor Otto IV against Philip II of France. Provide both the regnal name and number.

bonuses.leadin: In labor market diagrams, these policies represent the "price floor." For 10 points each:
answers: monopsony [accept word forms; accept monopsonistic competition]
parts: Name these policies, which establish the lowest price point at which workers may sell their labor.

In models where the labor market is considered to be this type of market, non-excessive minimum wages are believed to increase efficiency and labor participation. Labor markets of this type face upward sloping labor supply curves where employees act as wage searchers.

The work of these two economists has been used to argue that minimum wages do not hurt employment numbers. These two economists collaborated on the paper "Minimum Wages and Employment," which was later expanded as the book Myth and Measurement.

bonuses.leadin: Bartok frequently employed one type of this technique that involved snapping the string against the fingerboard. For 10 points each:
answers: Léo Delibes [or Clément Philibert Léo Delibes]
left hand pizzicato [accept mano sinistra; DO NOT accept “hammering down”]
parts: Name this technique of plucking the strings of an instrument instead of using a bow.
This composer wrote a commonly-excerpted pizzicato movement in Act III of his ballet Sylvia. The title priestess and her servant Mallika sing a “Flower Duet” in his opera Lakme.
Virtuosic pieces such as Paganini’s 24th Caprice and Sarasate’s Gypsy Airs make use of this type of pizzicato, which is denoted with a + (plus) sign above the note.

bonuses.leadin: After a Senator criticized an NEA award being given to an author of this surname, George Plimpton told him, “you are from the Midwest. You are culturally deprived, so you would not understand it anyway.” For 10 points each:
answers: Saroyan [accept Aram Saroyan or William Saroyan] (that novel is The Human Comedy)
parts: Give this surname of an author who won a $750 prize for a poem entirely consisting of the misspelled word “lighght.” This surname is shared by his father, who wrote about Homer Macaulay’s childhood in Ithaca, California.
William Saroyan burst onto the scene with a story about an unemployed former trapeze artist set during this economic downturn that began in 1929.
At the end of this 1935 play set during the Great Depression, a union of taxi cab drivers chant “Strike!” after learning the title character has been shot.

bonuses.leadin: Bacteria that can ferment this compound will turn a phenol red broth containing it yellow after 24 hours. For 10 points each:
answers: bacillus [accept bacillus subtilis or bacillus thuringiensis]
parts: Name this compound. The SacB gene commonly used as a negative selection reporter induces suicide from transformed organisms in the presence of this compound.

The SacB gene originates from the subtilis species of this bacterial genus. The thuringiensis species in this genus of Gram-positive, rod-shaped bacteria is frequently studied for its Cyt and Cry toxins.
B. subtilis produces the stably-folded monomer TasA, a major protein component of these structures, which contain cells bound to a matrix of extracellular polymers adhered onto a surface.

bonuses.leadin: George McJunkin discovered fluted points inside the skeleton of a bison at Folsom, which had thinner points than this nearby culture. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this culture to which the Anzick-1 boy belonged. It was named after a New Mexico town.

Dennis Stanford proposed this now widely-discredited hypothesis that the Clovis culture learned how to make their tools through “overshot” flaking taught to them by European peoples of the Upper Paleolithic.
Part of the Solutrean Hypothesis is that the Europeans used one of these structures to travel from Siberia to the Americas during periods of lower sea level.

bonuses.leadin: This text recommends “inner renunciation” in pursuing an active life to fulfill dharma. Commentaries on this work often synthesize bhakti into the Vedanta school. For 10 points each:
answers: war [accept a battle; prompt on answers like conflict or fighting]
parts: This text argues that gunas can only affect the ego and have no impact on the spirit. This text outlines the three yoga paths to obtain moksha as jñana (“NYAH-nuh”), bhakti, and karma.

The Bhagavad Gita is framed as a dialogue between Krishna and Arjuna as the latter determines whether to participate in one of these events due to the loss of life it will cause. St. Augustine provided the first defense for the "just" form of these events.

The Bhagavad Gita was consolidated into the doctrine of Advaita Vedanta by this philosopher. This philosopher argued for the unity of Atman and Nigurna Brahman, and discussed the nature of a “brahman without attributes.”

bonuses.leadin: In one short film created by this studio, an old man plays chess against himself, but still cheats to win. For 10 points each:
answers: umbrellas [or The Blue Umbrella; or The Umbrellas of Cherbourg]
parts: Name this animation studio behind "Geri's Game." This studio's feature length films include Cars and A Bug's Life, and it was acquired by Disney in 2006.
Domee Shi directed this Pixar short about a Chinese-Canadian woman dealing with empty nest syndrome after her son grows up and moves out. That son is represented by the title steamed bun.

Showings of Monsters University were preceded by a short about a blue one of these objects that becomes separated from his soulmate. Jacques Demy directed a musical titled for these objects that stars Catherine Denueve as Genevieve, who falls in love with a mechanic drafted into the Algerian war.

bonuses.leadin: Peukert’s law gives the change in capacity for one of these devices as a function of their discharge rate. For 10 points each:
answers: electric battery [accept lithium-ion battery, primary battery, or secondary battery]
potassium [or K; accept potassium hydroxide or KOH; accept potassium permanganate or KMnO4; prompt on caustic potash]
parts: Name these electrochemical devices that store and release power. UT Austin professor John Goodenough won the 2019 Nobel Prize in Chemistry for developing their lithium-ion variant.

Large grid storage systems commonly make use of “redox flow” batteries containing ions of this metal, since those ions can exist in four distinct oxidation states in solution. Since each oxidation state of this metal is a unique color, its zinc-mediated reduction is a common colorimetric lab experiment.

More conventional lithium-ion alternatives are nickel-cadmium batteries, which use an aqueous solution of this element’s hydroxide as their alkaline electrolyte. Baeyer’s reagent is a compound of this element, oxygen, and manganese.

bonuses.leadin: This novel is framed by two third person accounts which discuss the hideous appearance of a photo of this novel's narrator. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this Osamu Dazai novel, which follows Oda from his time as a child buffoon to an adult morphine addict and alcoholic.
No Longer Human may have been written in response to this other author's death. This author wrote the novel Kappa as well as short stories such as “Hell Screen.”
In 2019, Junji Ito developed a version of No Longer Human in this genre of literature. This Japanese word is used to refer to comic books like Ghost in the Shell and Sailor Moon.

bonuses.leadin: This figure was supposedly born as a lion, a deva, and as a denizen of hell, before his final birth in his most notable form. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this figure. At the age of 72, this figure attained kevalajñāna (kay-vula-nya-nuh) under the asalah tree as the 24th "fordmaker."

Mahavira was the most recent Tirthankara, the semi-mythical leaders of this religion. Members of this faith often wear masks over their mouths and sweep in front of their feet to avoid harming small creatures in accordance with the doctrine of ahimsa.

This figure is represented in the first auspicious dream as a white elephant, signifying his role as a guardian deity. This Vedic god legendarily controls the Panch Kalaya, and in many stories he serves as the teachers of the Tirthankaras.

bonuses.leadin: Nelson Miles coined the name of this scandal after being denounced by Charles Eagan. For 10 points each:
answers: embalmed beef [prompt on any answer including the terms army and beef with the question “What was the two-word term used for this scandal?”]
parts: Name this scandal, which erupted due to the inattentiveness of Russell Alger towards some low-quality meat.
The embalmed beef scandal took place during this war, in which the US invaded Cuba and Teddy Roosevelt rode with the Rough Riders.

Spanish sailors captured and executed 53 American and British sailors aboard this vessel for shipping arms to Cuba in the build-up to the Spanish-American War. Hamilton Fish extracted an indemnity of $80,000 for the families of the sailors killed aboard this ship.
